title: Acute Mesenteric Ischemia
diagnosis_topic: Embolic occlusion causing ischemia of the small intestine
setup_script: A 70-year-old woman with a history of atrial fibrillation on no anticoagulation presents with sudden severe abdominal pain out of proportion to exam findings. She is nauseated and vomited once. Her past medical history includes congestive heart failure and COPD.

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 130/70 mmHg, HR 110 bpm irregular, RR 22/min, Temp 38 C, SpO2 95%.
Abdomen soft, non-distended with mild tenderness, no peritonitis, bowel sounds decreased.
WBC 18 K/uL, lactate 6 mmol/L, ABG metabolic acidosis, INR 1.1.
CT angiography shows thrombotic occlusion of the superior mesenteric artery with non-enhancing segments of jejunum.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident starts resuscitation and broad-spectrum antibiotics
dynamic_flow.reply: Stabilizes hemodynamics and reduces progression of sepsis.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident consults vascular and general surgery
dynamic_flow.reply: Plan for emergent laparotomy with SMA embolectomy and resection of non-viable bowel.
Rapid progression to peritonitis and septic shock.
Second-look laparotomy in 24-48 hours to assess viability.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about risk factors
dynamic_flow.reply: Atrial fibrillation, low flow states, atherosclerosis.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about non-occlusive ischemia
dynamic_flow.reply: Caused by low flow (e.g., vasopressors) and treated by restoring perfusion.

critical_decision_points: Maintaining high index of suspicion when pain is out of proportion to exam
Planning for second-look surgery and managing complications
